concern:
Hi so I was not at school basically the last 2 weeks due to family reasons, and my partner for an assignment said it’s fine and to just add whatever I have to the doc & PowerPoint since I couldn’t meet up. We’re presenting on a chapter of a book we read in a couple hours and…I haven’t looked at the PowerPoint till I went to add my notes in last night and it’s all from cliff notes, spark notes and the first page of Google. Literally verbatim. What the shit am I supposed to do right now?

Update**** 
Forgot I posted this ngl

1.) Thanks for the advice, I was able to get an extension to Thursday by coincidence. My teacher canceled class 15 minutes beforehand.

2.) I didn’t abandon my partner to do the project alone, it’s a presentation on a book we’re reading in class and all of my information I put into a shared google doc. She didn’t give me access to the PowerPoint till the night before. Anyways, the family emergency was my mom needing a babysitter cause she was having a liver transplant and her original babysitter fell through so I was out of state for two weeks.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! How are you doing today? Is there anything in particular youd like to talk about?
I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed with school pressures lately. Yes, I'd like to talk about strategies for managing stress from my coursework and personal responsibilities.
That sounds like a lot on your plate. You mentioned both school pressures and personal responsibilitieswhich one feels more pressing at the moment?

School pressures are feeling more urgent right now, especially with upcoming deadlines and assignments. Personal responsibilities are still present, but I'm focusing on balancing them without letting them overwhelm me further.

It's great that you're aware of the need to balance everything. Regarding school pressures, what specific aspects of your coursework are causing the most stress? Is it time management, understanding the material, or something else?

The most stress is coming from time management, particularly with tight deadlines for assignments that I've had to juggle unexpectedly. I'm also finding it challenging to handle group work dynamics while trying to stay on top of everything.

It can be tough to manage your time when unexpected assignments pop up, and group work can definitely add another layer of complexity. When you say unexpectedly, do you mean that these assignments weren't on the syllabus or that you just didn't anticipate them taking so much time?

The assignments were on the syllabus, but I didn't anticipate them taking so much time due to some unforeseen personal circumstances. This has made it even more challenging to manage the dynamics of group work alongside my other responsibilities.

It sounds like you're in a tough spot, trying to balance schoolwork with unexpected personal circumstances. Despite the challenges, it's great that you're reaching out for support. Have you considered communicating with your group members andor professor about the situation?

Yes, I have considered communicating with my group members and professor, and I've already reached out to them about the situation to seek some flexibility. This has helped a little with my stress, but I'm still working on managing the overall balance between my coursework and personal responsibilities.

Therapist That's a positive step. Since communication has provided some relief, let's build on that. Would creating a prioritized schedule for the upcoming week or breaking down large tasks into smaller chunks be more helpful in managing your time?

I think creating a prioritized schedule for the upcoming week would be more helpful for me right now, as it could help me clearly outline my tasks and deadlines amidst my busy responsibilities. Breaking down large tasks into smaller chunks is also useful, but I'd like to start with scheduling to get a better overview of everything.

Therapist Great, creating a prioritized schedule can definitely help you gain a clearer picture of your tasks and deadlines. As you create your schedule, remember to allocate time for breaks and selfcare activities to avoid burnout. Would you like to set a time to check in next week to discuss your progress and any adjustments needed?

Yes, I'd like to set a time to check in next week to discuss my progress with the schedule and any adjustments needed. This will help me continue managing my school pressures and personal responsibilities more effectively.
